InButtonV2.name: InButtonV2
InButtonV2.title: In Button

metadata.description: A versatile button component with multiple variants and states. Supports solid, ghost, and text styling with various color themes.

accessibility.notes: Supports aria-label, proper button semantics, keyboard focus management

performance.notes: Lazy loads icon components, minimal re-renders

examples.title: Primary Button
examples.description: Most common button variant for primary call-to-action
examples.code:
<InButtonV2
  id="save-btn"
  type="primary"
  label-text="Save Changes"
  @click="handleSave"
/>

examples.title: Secondary Button
examples.description: For secondary actions or less prominent CTAs
examples.code:

  id="cancel-btn"
  type="secondary"
  label-text="Cancel"
  @click="handleCancel"
/>

examples.title: Danger Button
examples.description: For destructive actions like delete, remove

  id="delete-btn"

  label-text="Delete"

/>

examples.title: Loading State
examples.description: Show async operations in progress with spinner
examples.code:
<template>
  <InButtonV2
    id="save-btn"
    type="primary"
    label-text="Save"
    :loading-status="isLoading"
    @click="handleSave"
  />
</template>

<script setup>
import { ref } from 'vue';

const isLoading = ref(false);

const handleSave = async () => {
  isLoading.value = true;
  try {
    await api.save();
  } finally {
    isLoading.value = false;
  }
};
</script>

examples.title: Button Group
examples.description: Group related buttons together
examples.code:
<template>
  <InButtonV2
    id="period-selector"
    :button-group-options="periodOptions"
    @click="handlePeriodChange"
  />
</template>

<script setup>
import { ref } from 'vue';

const periodOptions = [
  { id: 'daily', type: 'secondary', styling: 'solid', labelText: 'Daily', selectedStatus: true },
  { id: 'weekly', type: 'secondary', styling: 'ghost', labelText: 'Weekly' },
  { id: 'monthly', type: 'secondary', styling: 'ghost', labelText: 'Monthly' }
];

const handlePeriodChange = (payload) => {
  console.log('Selected period:', payload.id);
};
</script>

InCheckBoxV2.name: InCheckBoxV2
InCheckBoxV2.title: In Check Box

metadata.description: Checkbox component with indeterminate state and size variants

InCheckBoxV2.typeDefs:
import { DefineComponent } from 'vue';

/**
 * Validation state variants for the checkbox.
 */
export type CheckboxState = 'default' | 'danger' | 'warning';

/**
 * Checkbox option for group mode.
 */
export interface CheckboxOption {
  /**
   * Display text for the checkbox option.
   */
  text: string;

  /**
   * Unique value for the checkbox option.
   */
  value: string | number;

  /**
   * Whether this option is checked by default.
   * @default false
   */
  checked?: boolean;
}

/**
 * Skeleton loader sizing configuration.
 */
export interface SkeletonSizing {
  /**
   * Skeleton width in pixels.
   */
  width: number;

  /**
   * Skeleton height in pixels.
   */
  height: number;
}

/**
 * InCheckBoxV2 component props.
 */
export interface InCheckBoxV2Props {
  /**
   * Unique identifier for the checkbox element.
   * Used for DOM manipulation, testing, and label association.
   *
   * @required
   * @example id="terms-checkbox"
   * @example id="subscribe-newsletter"
   */
  id: string;

  /**
   * Name attribute for the checkbox input.
   * Used in form submissions.
   *
   * @default ''
   * @example name="terms"
   * @example :name="123"
   */
  name?: string | number;

  /**
   * Label text displayed next to the checkbox.
   * Supports HTML content when preventXss is false.
   *
   * @default ''
   * @example label-text="I accept the terms and conditions"
   * @example label-text="Enable notifications"
   */
  labelText?: string;

  /**
   * Additional description text displayed below the label.
   * Provides more context about the checkbox option.
   *
   * @default ''
   * @example description-text="Receive updates about new features"
   */
  descriptionText?: string;

  /**
   * Validation or state message text.
   * Typically used for error or warning messages.
   *
   * @default ''
   * @example state-message="This field is required"
   * @example state-message="Please review the terms"
   */
  stateMessage?: string;

  /**
   * Enables tooltip display on the label.
   * Tooltip content comes from tooltipText prop.
   *
   * @default false
   * @example :tooltip-status="true"
   */
  tooltipStatus?: boolean;

  /**
   * Shows the description text below the label.
   * Must be true for descriptionText to be visible.
   *
   * @default false
   * @example :description-status="true"
   */
  descriptionStatus?: boolean;

  /**
   * Controls visibility of the label text.
   * When false, only the checkbox input is shown.
   *
   * @default true
   * @example :label-status="false"
   */
  labelStatus?: boolean;

  /**
   * Makes the label text bold.
   * Useful for emphasizing important checkboxes.
   *
   * @default false
   * @example :bold-label="true"
   */
  boldLabel?: boolean;

  /**
   * Tooltip content text.
   * Only shown when tooltipStatus is true.
   *
   * @default ''
   * @example tooltip-text="Additional information about this option"
   */
  tooltipText?: string;

  /**
   * Shows skeleton loading placeholder instead of checkbox.
   * Used during initial page load.
   *
   * @default false
   * @example :skeleton-status="isLoading"
   */
  skeletonStatus?: boolean;

  /**
   * Dimensions for the skeleton loader.
   * Only used when skeletonStatus is true.
   *
   * @default { width: 70, height: 24 }
   * @example :skeleton-sizing="{ width: 120, height: 32 }"
   */
  skeletonSizing?: SkeletonSizing;

  /**
   * Shows indeterminate state (dash icon).
   * Used for "select all" functionality when some items are selected.
   *
   * @default false
   * @example :indeterminate="someSelected && !allSelected"
   */
  indeterminate?: boolean;

  /**
   * Controls the checked state of the checkbox.
   * Use with v-model for two-way binding.
   *
   * @default false
   * @example :checked="isAccepted"
   * @example v-model="termsAccepted"
   */
  checked?: boolean;

  /**
   * Disables the checkbox, preventing user interaction.
   * Checkbox appears greyed out and cannot be toggled.
   *
   * @default false
   * @example :disabled-status="!canModify"
   */
  disabledStatus?: boolean;

  /**
   * Array of checkbox options for group mode.
   * When provided, renders multiple checkboxes in a group.
   *
   * @default []
   * @example
   * :options="[
   *   { text: 'Option 1', value: 'opt1', checked: true },
   *   { text: 'Option 2', value: 'opt2', checked: false }
   * ]"
   */
  options?: CheckboxOption[];

  /**
   * Validation state of the checkbox.
   * Affects border color and state message styling.
   *
   * @default 'default'
   * @example state="danger" // Red border for errors
   * @example state="warning" // Yellow border for warnings
   */
  state?: CheckboxState;
}

/**
 * Click event payload for single checkbox.
 */
export type SingleCheckboxClickPayload = boolean;

/**
 * Click event payload for checkbox group.
 */
export type CheckboxGroupClickPayload = Array<string | number>;

/**
 * Event handler types for InCheckBoxV2.
 */
export interface InCheckBoxV2EventHandlers {
  /**
   * Handler for click event.
   * For single checkbox, payload is boolean (checked state).
   * For checkbox groups, payload is array of selected values.
   *
   * @param payload - Boolean for single checkbox, array for checkbox group
   * @example
   * // Single checkbox
   * const handleClick = (checked: boolean) => {
   *   console.log('Checkbox is now:', checked);
   * }
   *
   * @example
   * // Checkbox group
   * const handleClick = (selected: Array<string | number>) => {
   *   console.log('Selected values:', selected);
   * }
   */
  onClick?: (payload: SingleCheckboxClickPayload | CheckboxGroupClickPayload) => void;
}

/**
 * InCheckBoxV2 Component
 *
 * Flexible checkbox component supporting single checkboxes, checkbox groups,
 * indeterminate state, validation states, and skeleton loading.
 *
 * @example
 * // Basic single checkbox
 * <InCheckBoxV2
 *   id="terms"
 *   name="terms"
 *   label-text="I accept the terms"
 *   :checked="accepted"
 *   @click="accepted = $event"
 * />
 *
 * @example
 * // With description
 * <InCheckBoxV2
 *   id="notifications"
 *   label-text="Enable notifications"
 *   description-text="Get email updates"
 *   :description-status="true"
 *   :checked="notificationsEnabled"
 *   @click="notificationsEnabled = $event"
 * />
 *
 * @example
 * // Indeterminate state
 * <InCheckBoxV2
 *   id="select-all"
 *   label-text="Select all"
 *   :checked="allSelected"
 *   :indeterminate="someSelected"
 *   @click="toggleAll"
 * />
 *
 * @example
 * // Checkbox group
 * <InCheckBoxV2
 *   id="interests"
 *   label-text="Select your interests"
 *   :options="[
 *     { text: 'Technology', value: 'tech', checked: true },
 *     { text: 'Design', value: 'design', checked: false }
 *   ]"
 *   @click="handleGroupSelection"
 * />
 *
 * @example
 * // With validation
 * <InCheckBoxV2
 *   id="required"
 *   label-text="Required field"
 *   state="danger"
 *   state-message="You must accept this"
 *   :checked="value"
 *   @click="value = $event"
 * />
 */
declare const InCheckBoxV2: DefineComponent<InCheckBoxV2Props>;

export default InCheckBoxV2;

examples.title: Form Validation with Error State
examples.description: Required checkbox with validation and error message
examples.code:
<template>
  <form @submit.prevent="handleSubmit">
    <InCheckBoxV2
      id="terms"
      name="terms"
      label-text="I accept the terms and conditions"
      :checked="formData.termsAccepted"
      :state="errors.terms ? 'danger' : 'default'"
      :state-message="errors.terms"
      @click="formData.termsAccepted = $event; validateTerms();"
    />
    
    <button type="submit" :disabled="!formData.termsAccepted">
      Continue
    </button>
  </form>
</template>

<script setup>
import { reactive, ref } from 'vue';

const formData = reactive({
  termsAccepted: false
});

const errors = ref({});

const validateTerms = () => {
  if (!formData.termsAccepted) {
    errors.value.terms = 'You must accept the terms to continue';
  } else {
    delete errors.value.terms;
  }
};

const handleSubmit = () => {
  validateTerms();
  if (Object.keys(errors.value).length === 0) {
    console.log('Form submitted!');
  }
};
</script>

examples.title: Skeleton Loading State
examples.description: Shows skeleton loader while checkbox data loads
examples.code:
<template>
  <InCheckBoxV2
    id="loading"
    name="loading"
    :skeleton-status="isLoading"
    :skeleton-sizing="{ width: 120, height: 24 }"
    label-text="Loading option..."
    :checked="value"
  />
</template>

<script setup>
import { ref, onMounted } from 'vue';

const isLoading = ref(true);
const value = ref(false);

onMounted(async () => {
  // Simulate API call
  await new Promise(resolve => setTimeout(resolve, 2000));
  isLoading.value = false;
});
</script>

commonMistakes.impact: Cannot track which checkbox was selected, events don't work properly
commonMistakes.fix: Always provide unique 'id' for each option: { id: 'unique-id', label: '...', value: '...' }

commonMistakes.mistake: Using same id for multiple options
commonMistakes.impact: Checkbox state conflicts, unpredictable behavior
commonMistakes.fix: Ensure each option has a unique id within the group

commonMistakes.mistake: Not handling click event with checkbox group
commonMistakes.impact: Selected values not tracked, state not updated
commonMistakes.fix: Use @click handler or v-model to track selected values: @click="handleClick"

valueFormat.notes: Defines dimensions for skeleton loader placeholder. Only used when skeletonStatus is true.

implementationPatterns.when: Integrating checkbox in forms with validation
implementationPatterns.code:
<template>
  <form @submit.prevent="handleSubmit">
    <InCheckBoxV2
      id="terms"
      name="terms"
      label-text="I accept the terms"
      :checked="formData.terms"
      :state="errors.terms ? 'danger' : 'default'"
      :state-message="errors.terms"
      @click="updateField('terms', $event)"
    />
    
    <button type="submit">Submit</button>
  </form>
</template>

<script setup>
import { reactive, ref } from 'vue';

const formData = reactive({ terms: false });
const errors = ref({});

const updateField = (field, value) => {
  formData[field] = value;
  validateField(field);
};

const validateField = (field) => {
  if (field === 'terms' && !formData.terms) {
    errors.value.terms = 'Required field';
  } else {
    delete errors.value.terms;
  }
};

const handleSubmit = () => {
  Object.keys(formData).forEach(validateField);
  if (Object.keys(errors.value).length === 0) {
    // Submit form
  }
};
</script>
implementationPatterns.notes: Always validate on change for immediate feedback. Use state prop for visual error indication.

implementationPatterns.when: Implementing bulk selection with master checkbox
implementationPatterns.code:
<script setup>
import { ref, computed } from 'vue';

const items = ref([1, 2, 3, 4, 5]);
const selectedItems = ref([]);

const allSelected = computed(() => 
  selectedItems.value.length === items.value.length && items.value.length > 0
);

const someSelected = computed(() => 
  selectedItems.value.length > 0 && !allSelected.value
);

const toggleAll = (checked) => {
  selectedItems.value = checked ? [...items.value] : [];
};

const toggleItem = (item, checked) => {
  if (checked) {
    selectedItems.value.push(item);
  } else {
    selectedItems.value = selectedItems.value.filter(i => i !== item);
  }
};
</script>

<template>
  <InCheckBoxV2
    id="select-all"
    label-text="Select all"
    :checked="allSelected"
    :indeterminate="someSelected"
    @click="toggleAll"
  />
  
  <InCheckBoxV2
    v-for="item in items"
    :key="item"
    :id="`item-${item}`"
    :label-text="`Item ${item}`"
    :checked="selectedItems.includes(item)"
    @click="(checked) => toggleItem(item, checked)"
  />
</template>
implementationPatterns.notes: Use computed properties for allSelected and someSelected states. Indeterminate only shows when some (but not all) items are selected.

examples.title: Server-Side Table with API
examples.description: Table fetching data from API endpoint with authentication
examples.code:
<template>
  <InDataTable
    name="api-table"
    api-mode
    fetch-url="/api/users"
    :table-search-params="searchParams"
    :table-fields="columns"
    :http-options="httpOptions"
    pagination-path="meta.pagination"
    :per-page="25"
    with-search-filter
    with-status-filter
    :status-list="statusOptions"
    @on-load="handleLoad"
  />
</template>

<script setup>
import { ref, computed } from 'vue';

const authToken = ref('Bearer your-token-here');
const tenantId = ref('tenant-123');

const httpOptions = computed(() => ({
  headers: {
    'Authorization': authToken.value,
    'X-Tenant-ID': tenantId.value
  }
}));

const searchParams = computed(() => ({
  tenant: tenantId.value
}));

const columns = ref([
  { field: 'id', label: 'ID', width: 80 },
  { field: 'name', label: 'Name', sortable: true },
  { field: 'email', label: 'Email', sortable: true },
  { field: 'status', label: 'Status' }
]);

const statusOptions = ref([
  { label: 'Active', value: 'active' },
  { label: 'Inactive', value: 'inactive' },
  { label: 'Pending', value: 'pending' }
]);

const handleLoad = (payload) => {
  console.log(`Loaded ${payload.data.length} rows`);
};
</script>

examples.title: Custom HTTP Client with Axios
examples.description: Using custom HTTP client for advanced request handling
examples.code:
<template>
  <InDataTable
    name="axios-table"
    api-mode
    fetch-url="/api/data"
    :http-fetch="axiosClient"
    :table-fields="columns"
    :per-page="20"
  />
</template>

<script setup>
import axios from 'axios';

const axiosClient = async (url, options) => {
  try {
    const response = await axios.get(url, {
      params: options?.params,
      headers: options?.headers,
      timeout: 10000 // 10 second timeout
    });
    
    // Convert axios response to fetch Response
    return new Response(JSON.stringify(response.data), {
      status: response.status,
      statusText: response.statusText,
      headers: new Headers(response.headers)
    });
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('API Error:', error);
    throw error;
  }
};

const columns = ref([
  { field: 'id', label: 'ID' },
  { field: 'name', label: 'Name', sortable: true }
]);
</script>

examples.title: Formatted Values
examples.description: Custom formatting for dates, currency, and status
examples.code:
<template>
  <InDataTable
    name="formatted-table"
    :data="transactions"
    :table-fields="columns"
    :format-mapping="formatters"
  />
</template>

<script setup>
import { ref } from 'vue';

const transactions = ref([
  { id: 1, amount: 1234.56, createdAt: '2025-01-15T10:30:00Z', status: 'completed' }
]);

const columns = ref([
  { field: 'id', label: 'ID' },
  { field: 'amount', label: 'Amount' },
  { field: 'createdAt', label: 'Date' },
  { field: 'status', label: 'Status' }
]);

const formatters = ref({
  amount: (value) => `$${parseFloat(value).toFixed(2)}`,
  createdAt: (value) => new Date(value).toLocaleDateString('en-US', {
    year: 'numeric',
    month: 'short',
    day: 'numeric'
  }),
  status: (value) => value.charAt(0).toUpperCase() + value.slice(1)
});
</script>

examples.title: Conditional Row Styling
examples.description: Dynamic row classes based on row data
examples.code:
<template>
  <InDataTable
    name="styled-table"
    :data="items"
    :table-fields="columns"
    :row-class="getRowClass"
  />
</template>

<script setup>
import { ref } from 'vue';

const items = ref([
  { id: 1, name: 'Item 1', status: 'error', priority: 'high' },
  { id: 2, name: 'Item 2', status: 'success', priority: 'low' }
]);

const columns = ref([
  { field: 'name', label: 'Name' },
  { field: 'status', label: 'Status' },
  { field: 'priority', label: 'Priority' }
]);

const getRowClass = (row) => {
  if (row.status === 'error') return 'bg-red-50 text-red-900';
  if (row.status === 'success') return 'bg-green-50';
  if (row.priority === 'high') return 'font-bold';
  return '';
};
</script>

<style scoped>
.bg-red-50 { background-color: #ffebee; }
.text-red-900 { color: #b71c1c; }
.bg-green-50 { background-color: #e8f5e9; }
</style>

commonMistakes.title: Using fetchUrl without apiMode=true
commonMistakes.description: Table needs apiMode enabled to fetch from URL
commonMistakes.impact: Table shows empty state, no data fetched

commonMistakes.title: Missing 'field' property in tableFields
commonMistakes.description: Each column definition must have 'field' matching data key
commonMistakes.impact: Columns show undefined values or don't render

commonMistakes.title: httpFetch not returning Promise<Response>
commonMistakes.description: Custom HTTP client must return proper Response object
commonMistakes.correct: :http-fetch="async (url, opts) => { const res = await axios.get(url); return new Response(JSON.stringify(res.data), { status: res.status }); }"
commonMistakes.impact: Table loading fails with type errors

commonMistakes.title: Missing Authorization header for protected APIs
commonMistakes.description: Authenticated endpoints require auth headers in httpOptions
commonMistakes.impact: API requests fail with 401 Unauthorized

commonMistakes.title: Wrong paginationPath for API response
commonMistakes.description: Path must match your API's pagination data location
commonMistakes.wrong: pagination-path="pagination" for API response { meta: { pagination: {...} } }
commonMistakes.impact: Pagination broken, wrong page counts

commonMistakes.title: Using 'title' instead of 'label' in tableFields
commonMistakes.description: V1 uses 'label' property for column headers
commonMistakes.impact: Column headers don't display

commonMistakes.title: Loading large datasets client-side
commonMistakes.description: Client-side mode not suitable for > 1000 rows
commonMistakes.impact: Page freezes, poor performance

commonMistakes.title: Complex logic in rowClass function
commonMistakes.description: rowClass called for every row on every render
commonMistakes.impact: Table re-renders slowly, performance issues

valueFormat.notes: REQUIRED: Array of column definition objects. Each must have 'field' and 'label' properties
examples: [{ field: 'id', label: 'ID', width: 80 }, { field: 'email', label: 'Email', sortable: true, renderer: 'email' }]
valueFormat.typescript: Array<{ field: string; label: string; sortable?: boolean; width?: number; renderer?: string; formatter?: Function; }>

commonMistakes.mistake: Not providing 'field' property in column definition
commonMistakes.impact: Column shows undefined or doesn't render
commonMistakes.fix: Each column must have: { field: 'propertyName', label: 'Display Name' }

commonMistakes.mistake: Using 'title' instead of 'label' for column header
commonMistakes.impact: Column header doesn't display
commonMistakes.fix: V1 uses 'label' property, not 'title'

commonMistakes.mistake: Field name doesn't match data object keys
commonMistakes.impact: Column shows empty values
commonMistakes.fix: Ensure field: 'email' matches data object key: { email: 'test@example.com' }

valueFormat.notes: CRITICAL: Custom HTTP client function for API requests. Use when you need custom auth, interceptors, or error handling. Replaces default fetch behavior

commonMistakes.mistake: Not returning a Promise from httpFetch
commonMistakes.impact: Table loading fails silently or throws errors
commonMistakes.fix: httpFetch must return Promise<Response>: async (url, options) => await fetch(url, options)

commonMistakes.impact: Custom fetch function never gets called
commonMistakes.fix: Always set api-mode when providing :http-fetch

commonMistakes.mistake: Not handling errors in custom httpFetch
commonMistakes.impact: Unhandled promise rejections, poor error UX
commonMistakes.fix: Wrap in try-catch and return proper Response: try { return await axios(...) } catch (e) { throw new Error(...) }

commonMistakes.mistake: Forgetting to merge httpOptions into custom fetch
commonMistakes.impact: Headers and credentials from httpOptions prop are ignored
commonMistakes.fix: Merge options: httpFetch: (url, opts) => fetch(url, { ...opts, ...httpOptions.value })

valueFormat.notes: Table data array for client-side mode (when apiMode=false). Each object represents a row

commonMistakes.impact: Confusing behavior - which data source is used depends on apiMode
commonMistakes.fix: Use :data for client-side OR fetch-url for server-side, not both

valueFormat.notes: API endpoint for server-side data fetching. Requires apiMode=true

commonMistakes.impact: Table doesn't fetch data, shows empty state
commonMistakes.fix: Always set api-mode when using fetch-url

commonMistakes.mistake: Not handling CORS for external APIs
commonMistakes.impact: API requests fail with CORS errors
commonMistakes.fix: Ensure API has proper CORS headers or use proxy

valueFormat.notes: Enable server-side data fetching. When true, uses fetchUrl instead of local data
Additional query parameters sent with API requests. Merged with pagination/sort/filter params
Row action buttons configuration. Creates action column with buttons for each row
valueFormat.typescript: Array<{ name: string; icon?: string; label?: string; handler?: (row: any) => void; }>

valueFormat.notes: Number of rows per page. Default: 10
Default sort configuration applied on initial load
JSON path to pagination data in API response. Uses dot notation for nested objects

commonMistakes.mistake: Wrong pagination path for API response structure
commonMistakes.impact: Pagination doesn't work, shows wrong page count
commonMistakes.fix: Inspect API response and set correct path: pagination-path="meta.pagination"

valueFormat.notes: HTTP request configuration for API calls (headers, credentials, etc.)

commonMistakes.mistake: Not providing Authorization header for authenticated APIs
commonMistakes.impact: API requests fail with 401 Unauthorized
commonMistakes.fix: Pass auth header: :http-options="{ headers: { 'Authorization': `Bearer ${token}` } }"

valueFormat.notes: Unique identifier field for row tracking. Critical for selection and detail rows. Default: 'id'

commonMistakes.impact: Row selection breaks, detail rows don't work properly
commonMistakes.fix: Use truly unique field: track-by="id" or track-by="uuid"

valueFormat.notes: Custom formatter functions for specific fields. Maps field names to formatter functions
Dynamic class applied to rows based on row data. Can be string or function

commonMistakes.impact: Performance issues - function called for every row on every render
commonMistakes.fix: Keep function simple or memoize results

valueFormat.notes: Type of loading indicator shown during data fetch

payloadFormat.notes: Emitted when table data is loaded (both initial and refreshes)

payloadFormat.structure: { page: number, perPage: number, total: number }
payloadFormat.notes: Emitted when pagination state changes (page change, perPage change)
Emitted with total record count from API response
Emitted when user changes per-page selection in pagination dropdown
Emitted when row selection changes. selectedRows contains full row objects

bestPractices.why: Ensures proper row identification and prevents selection bugs
bestPractices.antiPattern: Omitting trackBy with non-unique default 'id' field

bestPractices.why: Client-side rendering of large datasets causes performance issues

bestPractices.practice: Provide httpOptions for all authenticated API calls
bestPractices.why: Without auth headers, API requests will fail
bestPractices.antiPattern: Expecting table to inherit global axios interceptors

bestPractices.practice: Use formatMapping for consistent value formatting
bestPractices.why: Centralizes formatting logic, easier to maintain
bestPractices.antiPattern: Custom renderer components for simple formatting

bestPractices.practice: Set proper paginationPath for your API response structure
bestPractices.why: Incorrect path causes pagination to break
bestPractices.antiPattern: Guessing pagination path without inspecting API response

bestPractices.why: Complex functions hurt performance (called for every row on every render)

bestPractices.practice: Use loading states for better UX

commonMistakes.issue: V1 prop name won't work in V2
commonMistakes.solution: Rename tableFields to columnOptions and update column structure
V2 uses AG Grid format: use headerName instead of label

commonMistakes.mistake: Using api-mode boolean instead of row-model-type

commonMistakes.issue: Items per page not set correctly

commonMistakes.mistake: Not handling AG Grid column definition format
commonMistakes.issue: Advanced features like filters don't work
commonMistakes.solution: V2 uses AG Grid format - add filter: true, sortable: true explicitly

columnOptions.description: Column definitions array - replaces V1 tableFields

valueFormat.structure: Array of AG Grid column definitions
valueFormat.notes: CRITICAL: Defines table structure using AG Grid format (not V1 format!). Each column needs 'field' (data property) and 'headerName' (column title). Optional: sortable, filter, width, pinned ('left'/'right'), cellRenderer for custom rendering. V2 is built on AG Grid - use AG Grid column definition format with all its features (valueFormatter, cellClass, cellStyle, etc.).
valueFormat.typescript: Array<{ field: string; headerName: string; sortable?: boolean; filter?: boolean; width?: number; pinned?: 'left' | 'right'; cellRenderer?: string; valueFormatter?: Function; }>
valueFormat.example: :column-options="[{ field: 'name', headerName: 'Name', sortable: true, filter: true }, { field: 'email', headerName: 'Email', width: 200 }]"

commonMistakes.impact: Column headers display as undefined or blank
commonMistakes.fix: Change all 'label' to 'headerName' in column definitions

commonMistakes.impact: Custom cell renderers don't work, cells show raw data
commonMistakes.fix: Use AG Grid cellRenderer format with component name strings

data.description: Table data array for client-side mode

valueFormat.notes: Array of data objects to display in the table. Each object represents one row, with properties matching column 'field' values. Only used in clientSide rowModelType. For serverSide mode, data is fetched from API via fetchUrl. Update this array to refresh table content (reactive).

totalData.description: Total number of records (for server-side pagination display)

valueFormat.notes: Total record count for server-side pagination. Used to calculate total pages and show 'X of Y' items. Only relevant in serverSide rowModelType - in clientSide mode, total is auto-calculated from data array length. Backend should return this in API response.

rowModelType.description: Data loading mode - replaces V1 apiMode

valueFormat.notes: Determines how table loads data. 'clientSide' (default) loads all data upfront into browser - use for <1000 rows. 'serverSide' fetches data paginated from API via fetchUrl - use for large datasets (10K+ rows). 'infinite' enables infinite scroll. CRITICAL V1 CHANGE: V1 used boolean api-mode, V2 uses string row-model-type.

commonMistakes.impact: Prop not recognized, table doesn't fetch from API
commonMistakes.fix: Change :api-mode="true" to row-model-type="serverSide"

fetchUrl.description: API endpoint URL for server-side data fetching

valueFormat.notes: API endpoint URL for fetching table data in serverSide mode. Table will POST/GET (based on httpMethod) to this URL with pagination/filter/sort params. Requires rowModelType="serverSide". Backend should return data array and totalData count. Use tableSearchParams for additional custom params.

HTTP method used when fetching data from fetchUrl. GET sends params in query string, POST sends in request body. Use POST for complex filters or when URL length might exceed limits. Only relevant in serverSide rowModelType.

bulkActionsOptions.description: Bulk action buttons for selected rows

valueFormat.notes: Defines bulk action buttons shown when rows are selected. Each action needs id (unique identifier), label (button text). Optional: icon, variant ('danger' for destructive actions), disabled. Actions trigger @bulk-action event with actionId and selectedRows. Use for operations like export, delete, archive on multiple rows.
valueFormat.typescript: Array<{ id: string; label: string; icon?: string; variant?: string; disabled?: boolean; }>

valueFormat.notes: Shows bulk actions toolbar when rows are selected. Requires rowsSelection to be enabled and bulkActionsOptions to be provided. When true, toolbar appears above table showing action buttons and selected count. Essential for multi-row operations.

'multiple' allows selecting many rows with checkboxes, 'single' allows only one row selected at a time. Checkboxes appear in first column. Use with @select-status/@row-selected events to track selections. Essential for bulk operations or row-based actions.

canSelectAllRows.description: Enable select all checkbox in header

valueFormat.notes: Shows 'select all' checkbox in table header for selecting all rows at once. Only works with rowsSelection="multiple". When clicked, selects all visible rows (respects pagination). Use for bulk operations where users might want to select entire page.

rowHeight.description: Height of each row in pixels

valueFormat.notes: Row height preset or custom pixel value. 'small' (48px) for compact tables, 'medium' (64px) default for comfortable viewing, or custom number for specific height. Fixed row height improves scroll performance in large tables. AG Grid uses this for virtualization calculations.

Wraps entire table in InContainer component for consistent styling with headers, borders, shadows. Use inContainerLayoutOptions to configure container appearance (title, borders, etc.). Essential for matching Design System container patterns across application.

Configuration for InContainer wrapper when inContainerLayout=true. headerStatus adds header section, title sets header text, border adds container borders. Passes props directly to InContainer component. Use for consistent table presentation.
valueFormat.typescript: { headerStatus?: boolean; title?: string; border?: boolean; }

valueFormat.notes: Enables master-detail pattern with expandable rows showing nested tables. When row is expanded, shows child table with data from nestedTableFields columns. Perfect for ordersorder items, userspermissions, invoicesline items. Emit @nested-data-ready to load nested data.

valueFormat.structure: Array of column definitions (same as columnOptions)
valueFormat.notes: Column definitions for the nested/child table shown when row expands. Same format as columnOptions - AG Grid column definitions. Used with nestedTableStatus. Define columns for child data structure (e.g., order items have product, quantity, price columns).
valueFormat.typescript: Array<{ field: string; headerName: string; width?: number; }>

valueFormat.notes: Displays hierarchical/tree data with expand/collapse functionality. Rows can have child rows creating tree structure (org charts, file systems, category hierarchies). Use groupDataPath to define how to access child nodes. Rows show expand/collapse icons automatically.

groupDataPath.description: Path to child nodes in tree data

valueFormat.notes: Function that returns path to child nodes in tree data structure. Used with isTreeData. Function receives row data and should return array of property names leading to children. Example: for org hierarchy stored in row.children, return ['children']. For nested like row.org.children, return ['org', 'children'].

searchFilterStatus.description: Show search input - replaces V1 withSearchFilter

valueFormat.notes: Shows global search input above table for filtering rows. Searches across all columns (client-side) or sends search param to API (server-side). V1 CHANGE: V1 used withSearchFilter, V2 uses searchFilterStatus. Emits @set-search-value event with search query.

Placeholder text shown in search input when empty. Use descriptive text like 'Search users...', 'Find orders...'. Helps users understand what they can search for. Only relevant when searchFilterStatus=true.

statusFilterStatus.description: Show status filter dropdown - replaces V1 withStatusFilter

valueFormat.notes: Shows status filter dropdown above table for filtering by predefined statuses. Options come from statusFilterList. Common for filtering by Active/Inactive, Published/Draft, etc. V1 CHANGE: V1 used withStatusFilter, V2 uses statusFilterStatus.

statusFilterList.description: Options for status filter - replaces V1 statusList

valueFormat.notes: Status options for the filter dropdown. Each option needs label (display text) and value (filter value sent to API). Used with statusFilterStatus. V1 CHANGE: V1 used statusList, V2 uses statusFilterList. Common values: Active/Inactive, All statuses, Published/Draft.
valueFormat.typescript: Array<{ label: string; value: string | number; }>

valueFormat.notes: Shows pagination controls below table (page numbers, prev/next buttons). Essential for large datasets. Works in both clientSide (splits data array) and serverSide (fetches pages from API) modes. Emits @pagination-changed when page changes.

Shows dropdown to change items per page (10, 25, 50, 100). Options range from minItemPerPage to maxItemPerPage. Allows users to control page size. Emits @per-page-selected when changed. Use with paginationStatus.

defaultItemPerPage.description: Default number of items per page - replaces V1 perPage

valueFormat.notes: Initial/default page size when table loads. V1 CHANGE: V1 used perPage, V2 uses defaultItemPerPage. Common values: 10 (default), 25, 50, 100. Choose based on data density and user needs. Smaller for detailed rows, larger for simple data.
Minimum page size option in items-per-page dropdown. Usually 10 or 25. Prevents users from selecting too small page sizes that require excessive clicking. Used to generate dropdown options.
Maximum page size option in items-per-page dropdown. Usually 100 or 200. Prevents performance issues from rendering too many rows at once. Used to generate dropdown options (min, default, max, etc.).

showingItemsStatus.description: Show 'Showing X of Y items' text

valueFormat.notes: Shows text like 'Showing 1-25 of 1,523 items' below table. Helps users understand current view and total data size. Especially useful in serverSide mode to show total from backend. Part of pagination information section.

Shows entire pagination info section (page count text, page size selector). Master toggle for pagination UI elements. When false, hides all pagination info except page number buttons. Use to simplify UI for small datasets.

Triggers loading state overlay on table. Shows spinner or skeleton based on loadingType. Use while fetching data (initial load or refresh). Prevents user interaction during load. Emits @loading-status event when changed.

Shows skeleton placeholder rows instead of spinner during loading. Better UX for initial load - users see table structure. Number of skeleton columns from horizontalSkeletonsCount. Use for first load, loadingStatus for refreshes.
valueFormat.example: skeleton-status // Show skeleton during initial load

horizontalSkeletonsCount.description: Number of skeleton columns to show

valueFormat.notes: Number of skeleton columns to render during skeleton loading. Should match actual column count for best visual effect. Default is 6. Used only when skeletonStatus=true or loadingType='skeleton'.

'skeleton' shows placeholder rows (better for initial load), 'spinner' shows loading spinner (better for refreshes). Determines loading UI when loadingStatus=true. Skeleton provides better perceived performance.

Title text shown in loading overlay. Appears above spinner/skeleton. Use descriptive text like 'Loading data...', 'Fetching users...'. Provides context during wait. Only shows when loadingStatus=true.
Subtitle/description text in loading overlay. Appears below title. Use for additional context like 'Please wait', 'This may take a moment'. Optional, can be empty for minimal UI.

noDataTitleText.description: Title when no data - replaces V1 noDataTitle

valueFormat.notes: Title text shown in empty state when table has no data. V1 CHANGE: V1 used noDataTitle, V2 uses noDataTitleText. Use clear messages like 'No results found', 'No users yet'. Helps users understand empty table.
valueFormat.example: no-data-title-text="No results found" // Empty state title

noDataDescriptionText.description: Description when no data - replaces V1 noDataDescription

valueFormat.notes: Description text shown below title in empty state. V1 CHANGE: V1 used noDataDescription, V2 uses noDataDescriptionText. Provide helpful guidance like 'Try adjusting filters', 'Click + to add first item'. Actionable suggestions improve UX.
valueFormat.example: no-data-description-text="Try adjusting your filters" // Empty state hint

valueFormat.notes: Customization options for empty state. icon sets empty state icon, buttonText shows action button, buttonAction defines click handler. Use to add 'Clear Filters', 'Add First Item' buttons in empty state. Makes empty state actionable.
valueFormat.typescript: { icon?: string; buttonText?: string; buttonAction?: Function; }

autoHeight.description: Auto-adjust table height based on content

valueFormat.notes: Table height automatically fits content (no vertical scroll). Grows/shrinks with row count. Use for small, variable datasets. DON'T use with large datasets - causes performance issues. Conflicts with fixedHeight. AG Grid disables virtualization with autoHeight.

Sets fixed table height in pixels. Table scrolls vertically when content exceeds height. Use for large datasets to maintain consistent UI. Enables AG Grid virtualization for performance. Conflicts with autoHeight. Common values: 400, 500, 600px.

Enables horizontal scrolling when columns exceed table width. Essential for tables with many columns. Use with pinned columns to keep important columns visible while scrolling. AG Grid handles scroll virtualization automatically.

Limits how many columns can be pinned (fixed left/right). Prevents users from pinning too many columns which hurts UX. When limit reached, emits @max-columns-pinned event. Common limit: 2-3 columns. Use to balance flexibility with usability.

Enables Excel-like cell range selection with mouse drag or Shift+Click. Users can select rectangular cell ranges. Useful for copy-paste operations or bulk cell editing. AG Grid provides built-in range selection UI and keyboard shortcuts.

Allows selecting and copying text inside cells. When false, prevents text selection (better for row selection UX). When true, users can select cell content for copying. Trade-off: easier copy vs cleaner row selection interaction.

rowDragManaged.description: Enable row drag and drop reordering

valueFormat.notes: Enables dragging rows to reorder them. Shows drag handle in first column. Emits @row-drag-end/@row-drag-stopped events with new order. Perfect for priority lists, task ordering, manual sorting. Use @row-drag-stopped to persist new order to backend.

customColumnMenuItems.description: Custom items for column context menu

valueFormat.notes: Adds custom items to column header context menu (right-click menu). Each item needs name (label) and action (click handler). Optional icon. Use for column-specific operations like 'Export Column', 'Hide Column', 'Pin Column'. Extends default AG Grid menu.
valueFormat.typescript: Array<{ name: string; action: Function; icon?: string; }>

valueFormat.notes: Enables mobile-optimized responsive behavior. Table adapts layout for small screens - columns may stack, simplified interactions. Use for mobile-first or responsive applications. May hide some columns on small screens automatically.

tableSearchParams.description: Additional parameters to send with search/filter requests in server-side mode

valueFormat.notes: Only used in serverSide row model. Merged with pagination/filter params in API requests

commonMistakes.impact: Params are ignored, not sent to API (no API calls in clientSide)
commonMistakes.fix: Only use with row-model-type="serverSide" for API fetching

commonMistakes.impact: Param changes don't trigger table refresh
commonMistakes.fix: Use ref/reactive: const params = ref({ status: 'active' })

dataLoaded.description: Emitted when table data is loaded

dataReady.description: Emitted when grid is ready with data

firstDataRendered.description: Emitted when first data is rendered

rowSelected.payload: { node: RowNode, data: any, selected: boolean }

allRowsSelected.description: Emitted when all rows are selected

bulkAction.description: Emitted when bulk action is triggered

cellClicked.payload: { colId: string, data: any, value: any }

maxColumnsPinned.description: Emitted when max pinned columns reached

copied.description: Emitted when data is copied to clipboard

nestedDataReady.description: Emitted when nested table data is ready

rowGroupStatusChanged.description: Emitted when row group expand/collapse changes

loadingStatus.notes: Emitted when table starts/stops loading data. Useful for showing global loading indicators

rowDragEnter.description: Emitted when dragged row enters a drop zone
rowDragEnter.payload: { node: RowNode, overNode: RowNode, event: DragEvent }
rowDragEnter.notes: Fires when dragging row over another row. Use with row-drag-managed prop

rowDragMove.payload: { node: RowNode, overNode: RowNode, event: DragEvent }
rowDragMove.notes: Fires continuously while dragging. Use for visual feedback during drag

rowDragLeave.description: Emitted when dragged row leaves a drop zone
rowDragLeave.payload: { node: RowNode, overNode: RowNode, event: DragEvent }
rowDragLeave.notes: Fires when drag exits a row area. Use to clear hover states

rowDragCancel.description: Emitted when row drag operation is cancelled
rowDragCancel.notes: Fires when user cancels drag (ESC key or invalid drop). Use to reset UI state

rowDragStopped.description: Emitted when row drag operation stops (successful or not)
rowDragStopped.notes: Always fires at end of drag operation. Use for cleanup regardless of success/failure

bestPractices.practice: Use AG Grid column definition format

bestPractices.example: { field: 'date', headerName: 'Date', sortable: true, filter: 'agDateColumnFilter', valueFormatter: params => formatDate(params.value) }

examples.title: Basic V1 Date Range Picker
examples.description: Simple date range picker without custom ranges
examples.code:
<template>
  <InDatePicker
    id="date-picker"
    label="Select Period"
    :value="dateValue"
    :min-date="minDate"
    :max-date="maxDate"
    :locale="locale"
    :format-mapping="formatMapping"
    :additional-ranges="true"
    open-position="right"
    @update="handleUpdate" />
</template>

<script>
import { InDatePicker } from '@useinsider/design-system-vue';

export default {
  components: { InDatePicker },
  
  data() {
    return {
      startDate: '01/12/2024',
      endDate: '20/12/2024',
      minDate: '01/01/2023',
      maxDate: new Date().toLocaleDateString('en-US'),
      locale: 'en-US',
      formatMapping: {
        'en-US': 'mm/dd/yyyy',
        'tr-TR': 'dd.mm.yyyy',
        'default': 'mm/dd/yyyy'
      }
    };
  },
  
  computed: {
    dateValue() {
      // V1: Plain object (NOT array)
      return {
        startDate: this.startDate,
        endDate: this.endDate
      };
    }
  },
  
  methods: {
    handleUpdate(rangeStr) {
      // V1 always returns string: "mm/dd/yyyy-mm/dd/yyyy"
      const [start, end] = rangeStr.split('-');
      this.startDate = start;
      this.endDate = end;
      
      console.log('Date range selected:', { start, end });
    }
  }
};
</script>

examples.title: With Custom Ranges & Disabled Dates
examples.description: V1 date picker with custom quick ranges and disabled date range
examples.code:
<template>
  <InDatePicker
    id="date-picker-custom"
    label="Reporting Period"
    :value="dateValue"
    :custom-date-range="true"
    :custom-ranges="customRanges"
    :disabled-range="disabledRange"
    :additional-ranges="true"
    :locale="locale"
    :format-mapping="formatMapping"
    open-position="center"
    @update="handleUpdate" />
</template>

<script>
import { InDatePicker } from '@useinsider/design-system-vue';

export default {
  components: { InDatePicker },
  
  data() {
    return {
      startDate: '10/01/2024',
      endDate: '12/31/2024',
      locale: 'en-US',
      formatMapping: {
        'en-US': 'mm/dd/yyyy',
        'default': 'mm/dd/yyyy'
      },
      // V1 custom ranges: Object with Date arrays
      customRanges: {
        'Q4 2024': [new Date('2024-10-01'), new Date('2024-12-31')],
        'Q3 2024': [new Date('2024-07-01'), new Date('2024-09-30')],
        'H2 2024': [new Date('2024-07-01'), new Date('2024-12-31')],
        'Full Year': [new Date('2024-01-01'), new Date('2024-12-31')]
      },
      // V1 disabled range: Unix timestamps in SECONDS
      disabledRange: [
        Math.floor(new Date('2024-12-25').getTime() / 1000), // Christmas
        Math.floor(new Date('2024-12-26').getTime() / 1000)
      ]
    };
  },
  
  computed: {
    dateValue() {
      return {
        startDate: this.startDate,
        endDate: this.endDate
      };
    }
  },
  
  methods: {
    handleUpdate(rangeStr) {
      const [start, end] = rangeStr.split('-');
      this.startDate = start;
      this.endDate = end;
      
      // Update analytics or fetch data
      this.fetchReportData(start, end);
    },
    
    fetchReportData(startDate, endDate) {
      console.log('Fetching data for:', startDate, 'to', endDate);
      // API call here
    }
  }
};
</script>

examples.title: Turkish Locale with Dot Format
examples.description: V1 date picker configured for Turkish locale with dd.mm.yyyy format
examples.code:
<template>
  <InDatePicker
    id="date-picker-tr"
    label="Tarih Aral Sein"
    :value="dateValue"
    :locale="'tr-TR'"
    :format-mapping="formatMapping"
    :additional-ranges="true"
    :custom-date-range="true"
    :custom-ranges="customRanges"
    separator=" - "
    @update="handleUpdate" />
</template>

<script>
import { InDatePicker } from '@useinsider/design-system-vue';

export default {
  components: { InDatePicker },
  
  data() {
    return {
      startDate: '01.12.2024',
      endDate: '31.12.2024',
      formatMapping: {
        'tr-TR': 'dd.mm.yyyy',
        'default': 'dd.mm.yyyy'
      },
      customRanges: {
        'Son eyrek': [new Date('2024-10-01'), new Date('2024-12-31')],
        'Bu Yl': [new Date('2024-01-01'), new Date('2024-12-31')]
      }
    };
  },
  
  computed: {
    dateValue() {
      return {
        startDate: this.startDate,
        endDate: this.endDate
      };
    }
  },
  
  methods: {
    handleUpdate(rangeStr) {
      // Note: rangeStr is still in mm/dd/yyyy format from component
      // Need to convert to dd.mm.yyyy for Turkish display
      const [start, end] = rangeStr.split('-');
      this.startDate = this.convertToTurkishFormat(start);
      this.endDate = this.convertToTurkishFormat(end);
    },
    
    convertToTurkishFormat(usDateStr) {
      // Convert mm/dd/yyyy to dd.mm.yyyy
      const [month, day, year] = usDateStr.split('/');
      return `${day}.${month}.${year}`;
    }
  }
};
</script>

valueFormat.notes: CRITICAL: V1 uses plain object, NOT array like V2. Date format depends on locale setting. Use mm/dd/yyyy for US locale, dd.mm.yyyy for EU/TR locales.

migrationToV2.notes: V2 requires array to support comparison mode

commonMistakes.mistake: Passing array format like V2: [{ startDate, endDate }]
commonMistakes.impact: Component won't render dates, shows empty picker
commonMistakes.fix: Remove array wrapper, use plain object: { startDate, endDate }

commonMistakes.mistake: Passing Date objects instead of strings
commonMistakes.impact: Type error, component may crash
commonMistakes.fix: Convert to string: { startDate: '01/12/2024', endDate: '20/12/2024' }

commonMistakes.mistake: Wrong date format for locale (e.g., mm/dd/yyyy for Turkish locale)
commonMistakes.impact: Date parsing fails, shows invalid dates
commonMistakes.fix: Match format to locale: dd.mm.yyyy for tr-TR, mm/dd/yyyy for en-US

valueFormat.notes: CRITICAL: V1 uses object with Date array values. Keys are display labels. Values MUST be native Date objects, NOT strings.

migrationToV2.v2Format: Array<{ name: string, title: string, startDate: string, endDate: string }>
migrationToV2.transformation: Object.entries(v1CustomRanges).map(([title, dates], i) => ({ name: `custom${i+1}`, title, startDate: formatDateToSlash(dates[0]), endDate: formatDateToSlash(dates[1]) }))
migrationToV2.notes: V2 uses array with mm/dd/yyyy string format

commonMistakes.mistake: Using string dates instead of Date objects: { 'Q4': ['10/01/2024', '12/31/2024'] }
commonMistakes.impact: Component won't render custom ranges, buttons don't appear
commonMistakes.fix: Use Date objects: { 'Q4': [new Date('2024-10-01'), new Date('2024-12-31')] }

commonMistakes.mistake: Passing V2 array format with name/title properties
commonMistakes.impact: Type error, custom ranges won't work
commonMistakes.fix: Use V1 object format with Date arrays

commonMistakes.mistake: Not setting customDateRange prop to true
commonMistakes.impact: Custom ranges won't be displayed even if provided
commonMistakes.fix: Add :custom-date-range="true" to enable custom ranges

valueFormat.notes: CRITICAL: V1 uses Unix timestamps in SECONDS (not milliseconds). Array of two numbers: [start, end]. Dates in this range will be disabled.

migrationToV2.transformation: { startDate: formatDate(new Date(v1[0] * 1000)), endDate: formatDate(new Date(v1[1] * 1000)) }
migrationToV2.notes: V2 uses object with date strings

commonMistakes.mistake: Using milliseconds instead of seconds: [Date.now(), Date.now()]
commonMistakes.impact: Incorrect date range disabled, may disable dates far in future
commonMistakes.fix: Convert to seconds: [Math.floor(Date.now() / 1000), Math.floor(endDate.getTime() / 1000)]

commonMistakes.impact: Type error, disabled range won't work
commonMistakes.fix: Convert to Unix timestamps in seconds: [date.getTime() / 1000, ...]

commonMistakes.mistake: Using V2 object format: { startDate, endDate }
commonMistakes.impact: Type error, disabled range won't work
commonMistakes.fix: Use array of Unix timestamps: [startTimestamp, endTimestamp]

valueFormat.notes: Maps locale codes to date format strings. Must match format used in value prop. Common formats: mm/dd/yyyy (US), dd.mm.yyyy (EU/TR), dd/mm/yyyy (GB).

commonMistakes.impact: Component may not format dates correctly for unmapped locales
commonMistakes.fix: Always include 'default' key: { 'default': 'dd.mm.yyyy', ... }

commonMistakes.mistake: Format string doesn't match value prop format
commonMistakes.impact: Date parsing/display mismatch, shows wrong dates
commonMistakes.fix: Ensure formatMapping matches value date format

valueFormat.notes: Controls calendar popover position. Renamed to 'calendarPopoverAlign' in V2.
Shows extended set of quick ranges (Last 30 Days, This Month, Last Month, etc.). Replaced with more flexible 'defaultRanges' array in V2.

migrationToV2.notes: V2 uses array for granular control

commonMistakes.mistake: Expecting customRanges to show without setting customDateRange=true
commonMistakes.impact: Custom ranges won't appear
commonMistakes.fix: Set both :custom-date-range="true" and provide :custom-ranges

valueFormat.notes: Enables single date selection mode. When true, only startDate is used. Renamed to 'singleDatePickerStatus' in V2.

commonMistakes.impact: endDate is ignored, may cause confusion
commonMistakes.fix: When single mode, only set startDate in value object

update.useCase: Emitted when user selects a date range and clicks apply. V1 always returns string (no comparison support).

migrationToV2.notes: V2 can return array when comparison is active. Must check Array.isArray(payload) in V2 handler.

commonMistakes.impact: String.split() will fail if checking Array.isArray() first
commonMistakes.fix: V1 always returns string, no array check needed

commonMistakes.impact: Component won't reflect user selection
commonMistakes.fix: Update startDate/endDate in data() and use computed for value

helperFunctions.name: convertToUnixTimestamp

InDatePickerV2.name: InDatePickerV2
InDatePickerV2.title: In Date Picker

metadata.description: Advanced date picker with single date, date range, and comparison modes. Features quick range selection, custom ranges, date constraints, and multi-locale support.

accessibility.notes: Supports keyboard navigation (Tab, Enter, Arrow keys), proper label association, state announcements, and focus management. Calendar navigation is fully keyboard accessible.

performance.notes: Complex calendar rendering with dual calendars in comparison mode. Uses masked input for date entry. Optimized with v-show for calendar visibility. Consider lazy loading for applications not requiring date selection on initial load.

modes.dateRange: Select a start and end date range
modes.comparison: Select two date ranges for comparison (e.g., current period vs previous period)

features.quickRanges: Pre-defined quick selection buttons (Today, Yesterday, Last Week, etc.)
features.customRanges: Add custom date ranges to quick selection
features.dateConstraints: Min/max date restrictions with disabled date ranges
features.comparison: Compare two date periods with automatic previous period calculation
features.localization: Support for multiple date formats (US, UK, Turkish, etc.)
features.timezone: Timezone offset support for international applications
features.validation: Real-time date validation with custom error messages
features.specialDates: Highlight specific dates with custom colors and labels

useCases: Analytics dashboards with date range selection

examples.title: Basic Date Range Picker
examples.description: Simple date range picker without comparison
examples.code:
<template>
  <InDatePickerV2
    id="date-picker"
    name="date-picker"
    theme="white"
    label-text="Select Period"
    :value="dateValue"
    :min-date="minDate"
    :max-date="maxDate"
    :locale="locale"
    :format-mapping="formatMapping"
    :quick-range-selection-status="true"
    @apply="handleApply" />
</template>

<script>
import { InDatePickerV2 } from '@useinsider/design-system-vue';

export default {
  components: { InDatePickerV2 },
  
  data() {
    return {
      startDate: '01.12.2024',
      endDate: '20.12.2024',
      minDate: '01.01.2023',
      maxDate: new Date(),
      locale: 'tr-TR',
      formatMapping: {
        'tr-TR': 'dd.mm.yyyy',
        'en-US': 'mm/dd/yyyy',
        'default': 'dd.mm.yyyy'
      }
    };
  },
  
  computed: {
    dateValue() {
      return [{
        startDate: this.startDate,
        endDate: this.endDate
      }];
    }
  },
  
  methods: {
    handleApply(payload) {
      // payload is string: "mm/dd/yyyy-mm/dd/yyyy"
      const [start, end] = payload.split('-');
      this.startDate = this.convertToLocalFormat(start);
      this.endDate = this.convertToLocalFormat(end);
    },
    
    convertToLocalFormat(dateStr) {
      // Convert mm/dd/yyyy to dd.mm.yyyy for Turkish locale
      const [month, day, year] = dateStr.split('/');
      return `${day}.${month}.${year}`;
    }
  }
};
</script>

examples.title: With Comparison & Dynamic Ranges
examples.description: Full-featured date picker with comparison mode and dynamically calculated comparison ranges
examples.code:
<template>
  <InDatePickerV2
    :key="`${datePickerKey}-${startDate}-${endDate}`"
    id="date-picker-compare"
    name="date-picker-compare"
    theme="white"
    label-text="Select Period"
    :value="datePickerValue"
    :min-date="minDate"
    :max-date="maxDate"
    :locale="locale"
    :format-mapping="formatMapping"
    :comparison-status="true"
    :disabled-comparison-status="compareDisabled"
    :quick-range-selection-status="true"
    :custom-ranges="customRangesForV2"
    :compared-custom-ranges="comparedCustomRangesForV2"
    @apply="handleApply"
    @periodSelected="handlePeriodSelected"
    @openComparison="handleOpenComparison"
    @closeComparison="handleCloseComparison" />
</template>

<script>
import { InDatePickerV2 } from '@useinsider/design-system-vue';

export default {
  components: { InDatePickerV2 },
  
  data() {
    return {
      datePickerKey: 0,
      startDate: '01.12.2024',
      endDate: '20.12.2024',
      comparisonStartDate: '',
      comparisonEndDate: '',
      isComparisonActive: false,
      compareDisabled: false,
      comparedCustomRangesForV2: [],
      minDate: '01.01.2023',
      maxDate: new Date(),
      locale: 'tr-TR',
      formatMapping: {
        'tr-TR': 'dd.mm.yyyy',
        'en-US': 'mm/dd/yyyy',
        'default': 'dd.mm.yyyy'
      },
      customDateRanges: {
        'Q4 2024': [new Date('2024-10-01'), new Date('2024-12-31')],
        'Last Quarter': [new Date('2024-07-01'), new Date('2024-09-30')]
      }
    };
  },
  
  computed: {
    datePickerValue() {
      const main = {
        startDate: this.startDate,
        endDate: this.endDate
      };
      
      if (this.isComparisonActive && this.comparisonStartDate && this.comparisonEndDate) {
        return [
          main,
          {
            startDate: this.comparisonStartDate,
            endDate: this.comparisonEndDate
          }
        ];
      }
      
      return [main];
    },
    
    customRangesForV2() {
      return Object.entries(this.customDateRanges).map(([title, dates], index) => ({
        name: `custom${index + 1}`,
        title,
        startDate: this.formatDateToSlash(dates[0]),
        endDate: this.formatDateToSlash(dates[1])
      }));
    }
  },
  
  methods: {
    handlePeriodSelected(range) {
      // Recalculate dynamic comparison ranges
      const start = this.parseDate(range.start);
      const end = this.parseDate(range.end);
      const periodLength = Math.floor((end - start) / (1000 * 60 * 60 * 24)) + 1;
      
      // Previous Period
      const prevEnd = new Date(start);
      prevEnd.setDate(start.getDate() - 1);
      const prevStart = new Date(prevEnd);
      prevStart.setDate(prevEnd.getDate() - periodLength + 1);
      
      // Previous Period Last Year
      const lastYearStart = new Date(prevStart);
      lastYearStart.setFullYear(prevStart.getFullYear() - 1);
      const lastYearEnd = new Date(prevEnd);
      lastYearEnd.setFullYear(prevEnd.getFullYear() - 1);
      
      this.comparedCustomRangesForV2 = [{
        name: 'lastYear',
        title: 'Previous Period Last Year',
        startDate: this.formatDateToSlash(lastYearStart),
        endDate: this.formatDateToSlash(lastYearEnd)
      }];
    },
    
    handleApply(payload) {
      if (Array.isArray(payload)) {
        // With comparison
        const [mainRange, comparisonRange] = payload;
        this.applyDateRange(mainRange);
        this.applyComparisonRange(comparisonRange);
      } else {
        // Single range
        this.applyDateRange(payload);
      }
    },
    
    applyDateRange(rangeStr) {
      const [start, end] = rangeStr.split('-');
      this.startDate = this.convertToLocalFormat(start);
      this.endDate = this.convertToLocalFormat(end);
    },
    
    applyComparisonRange(rangeStr) {
      const [start, end] = rangeStr.split('-');
      this.comparisonStartDate = this.convertToLocalFormat(start);
      this.comparisonEndDate = this.convertToLocalFormat(end);
    },
    
    handleOpenComparison() {
      this.isComparisonActive = true;
    },
    
    handleCloseComparison() {
      this.isComparisonActive = false;
      this.comparisonStartDate = '';
      this.comparisonEndDate = '';
    },
    
    formatDateToSlash(date) {
      const d = new Date(date);
      const month = String(d.getMonth() + 1).padStart(2, '0');
      const day = String(d.getDate()).padStart(2, '0');
      const year = d.getFullYear();
      return `${month}/${day}/${year}`;
    },
    
    parseDate(dateStr) {
      const parts = dateStr.split(/[/.]/); 
      const isSlash = dateStr.includes('/');
      
      if (isSlash) {
        // mm/dd/yyyy
        const [month, day, year] = parts;
        return new Date(parseInt(year), parseInt(month) - 1, parseInt(day));
      } else {
        // dd.mm.yyyy
        const [day, month, year] = parts;
        return new Date(parseInt(year), parseInt(month) - 1, parseInt(day));
      }
    },
    
    convertToLocalFormat(dateStr) {
      const [month, day, year] = dateStr.split('/');
      return `${day}.${month}.${year}`;
    }
  }
};
</script>

valueFormat.notes: Defines the dropdown items. Each option must have 'label' (display text) and 'value' (selected value). Optional: 'disabled' to prevent selection, 'description' for tooltips. For nested dropdowns, include 'children' array.
valueFormat.typescript: Array<{ label: string; value: string | number; disabled?: boolean; description?: string; children?: Array<DropdownOption> }>

valueFormat.notes: Current selected value that matches the 'value' property of an option. Use v-model for two-way binding. Can be string, number, or boolean depending on your option values. Empty string means no selection.

customOptionsKey.description: Custom property name for option label

valueFormat.notes: Maps custom property names from your data to dropdown's expected format. Use when your API returns objects with different property names than 'label' and 'value'. Example: if API returns [{name: 'John', id: 1}], use ['name', 'id'] to map namelabel and idvalue.

API endpoint URL to fetch dropdown options dynamically. When set, component will fetch options from this endpoint on mount or when search query changes. Use with 'responseKey' to extract data from nested responses and 'queryString' for search parameter name.

responseKey.description: JSON path to options in API response

valueFormat.notes: Dot-notation path to extract options array from API response. CRITICAL for API fetching. If API returns {data: {items: [...]}}, use 'data.items'. If response is flat array at root, leave empty or use 'data' if responseHasData=true.

Name of the query parameter for search functionality when using API fetch. The search input value will be sent as this parameter. Example: if queryString='search', API will be called with ?search=userInput. Requires searchStatus=true and fetchUrl to be set.

Forces dropdown menu to open in specific direction, overriding automatic positioning. Use 'top' to open above the button (useful when dropdown is near bottom of viewport), 'bottom' to open below. If not set, component auto-positions based on available space.

Dropdown behavior variant. 'default' for standard single-level dropdown. 'nested' enables hierarchical options with child menus (requires options with 'children' property). Use nested type for category/subcategory structures.

Visual style of the dropdown trigger button. 'dropdown' (default) for standard dropdown appearance, 'primary' for prominent actions, 'secondary' for less emphasis, 'ghost' for minimal styling. Affects button colors and borders.

Size of the dropdown trigger button. 'default' (40px height), 'small' (32px), 'large' (48px). Affects button height, padding, and font size. Use 'small' in compact UIs, 'large' for emphasis or touch-friendly interfaces.

Horizontal position (in pixels) of child dropdown menu for nested options. Only applies when type='nested'. Use string value ('left' or 'right') for relative positioning, or number for absolute pixel offset. Controls where nested submenu appears relative to parent menu.

When true, shows an 'X' button to clear the current selection and reset dropdown to empty state. Useful for optional fields where user might want to unselect. When false, selection is permanent until user picks another option.

Enables adding new options on-the-fly when user types value not in the options list. Shows 'Add new option' button in dropdown. When clicked, emits 'addNewOption' event with the typed value. Useful for tags, categories, or dynamic lists where user can create entries.

addNewOption.description: Emitted when new option is created

bestPractices.practice: Use searchStatus for large option lists
bestPractices.description: Enable search when options > 10
Use invalid/warning with messages

metadata.description: Dropdown menu component for navigation and actions

InDropdownMenu.typeDefs:
import { DefineComponent } from 'vue';

/**
 * Menu option structure for dropdown items.
 */
export interface MenuOption {
  /**
   * Display text for the menu item.
   */
  text: string;

  /**
   * Unique value for the menu item.
   * Returned in select event when item is clicked.
   */
  value: string | number;

  /**
   * Optional icon name to display with the menu item.
   * Icon names should match InIcons component icon set.
   *
   * @example icon="user"
   * @example icon="settings"
   */
  icon?: string;

  /**
   * Nested submenu items.
   * Creates a hierarchical menu structure.
   *
   * @example
   * children: [
   *   { text: 'Export as PDF', value: 'pdf' },
   *   { text: 'Export as CSV', value: 'csv' }
   * ]
   */
  children?: MenuOption[];

  /**
   * Whether this menu item is disabled.
   * Disabled items are visible but not clickable.
   *
   * @default false
   */
  disabled?: boolean;

  /**
   * Whether this menu item is a divider (separator line).
   * When true, renders a horizontal line instead of a menu item.
   *
   * @default false
   */
  divider?: boolean;
}

/**
 * InDropdownMenu component props.
 */
export interface InDropdownMenuProps {
  /**
   * Unique identifier for the dropdown menu element.
   *
   * @required
   * @example id="user-menu"
   * @example id="actions-dropdown"
   */
  id: string;

  /**
   * Array of menu items to display.
   * Supports nested items via children property.
   *
   * @required
   * @example
   * :options="[
   *   { text: 'Profile', value: 'profile', icon: 'user' },
   *   { text: 'Settings', value: 'settings', icon: 'settings' },
   *   { text: 'Logout', value: 'logout', icon: 'logout' }
   * ]"
   *
   * @example
   * // With nested submenu
   * :options="[
   *   { text: 'New', value: 'new', icon: 'plus' },
   *   {
   *     text: 'Export',
   *     value: 'export',
   *     icon: 'download',
   *     children: [
   *       { text: 'PDF', value: 'export-pdf' },
   *       { text: 'CSV', value: 'export-csv' }
   *     ]
   *   }
   * ]"
   */
  options: MenuOption[];

  /**
   * Controls the open/close state of the dropdown.
   * Use to programmatically show or hide the menu.
   *
   * @default false
   * @example :status="isMenuOpen"
   * @example :status="showDropdown"
   */
  status?: boolean;

  /**
   * Enables search/filter functionality in the dropdown.
   * Shows a search input at the top of the menu.
   *
   * @default false
   * @example :search-status="true"
   */
  searchStatus?: boolean;

  /**
   * Shows loading indicator in the dropdown.
   * Useful for async data loading scenarios.
   *
   * @default false
   * @example :loading-state="isFetchingOptions"
   */
  loadingState?: boolean;
}

/**
 * Event handler types for InDropdownMenu.
 */
export interface InDropdownMenuEventHandlers {
  /**
   * Handler for select event when menu item is clicked.
   * Receives the value of the selected menu item.
   *
   * @param value - The value of the selected menu item
   * @example
   * const handleSelect = (value: string | number) => {
   *   console.log('Selected:', value);
   *   if (value === 'logout') {
   *     performLogout();
   *   }
   * }
   */
  onSelect?: (value: string | number) => void;

  /**
   * Handler for search event when search input changes.
   * Only emitted when searchStatus is true.
   *
   * @param query - Search query string
   * @example
   * const handleSearch = (query: string) => {
   *   filteredOptions.value = options.filter(opt =>
   *     opt.text.toLowerCase().includes(query.toLowerCase())
   *   );
   * }
   */
  onSearch?: (query: string) => void;
}

/**
 * InDropdownMenu Component
 *
 * Flexible dropdown menu component with nested submenus, icons,
 * search functionality, and keyboard navigation.
 *
 * @example
 * // Basic dropdown menu
 * <InDropdownMenu
 *   id="actions"
 *   :options="[
 *     { text: 'Edit', value: 'edit', icon: 'edit' },
 *     { text: 'Delete', value: 'delete', icon: 'trash' }
 *   ]"
 *   :status="menuOpen"
 *   @select="handleAction"
 * />
 *
 * @example
 * // User profile menu
 * <template>
 *   <button @click="toggleMenu">
 *     {{ userName }}
 *   </button>
 *
 *   <InDropdownMenu
 *     id="profile-menu"
 *     :options="profileOptions"
 *     :status="menuOpen"
 *     @select="handleMenuAction"
 *   />
 * </template>
 *
 * <script setup>
 * import { ref } from 'vue';
 *
 * const menuOpen = ref(false);
 * const profileOptions = [
 *   { text: 'Profile', value: 'profile', icon: 'user' },
 *   { text: 'Settings', value: 'settings', icon: 'settings' },
 *   { divider: true },
 *   { text: 'Logout', value: 'logout', icon: 'logout' }
 * ];
 *
 * const toggleMenu = () => {
 *   menuOpen.value = !menuOpen.value;
 * };
 * </script>
 *
 * @example
 * // Nested submenu
 * <InDropdownMenu
 *   id="file-menu"
 *   :options="[
 *     { text: 'New', value: 'new', icon: 'plus' },
 *     {
 *       text: 'Export',
 *       value: 'export',
 *       icon: 'download',
 *       children: [
 *         { text: 'Export as PDF', value: 'export-pdf' },
 *         { text: 'Export as CSV', value: 'export-csv' },
 *         { text: 'Export as JSON', value: 'export-json' }
 *       ]
 *     },
 *     { text: 'Print', value: 'print', icon: 'printer' }
 *   ]"
 *   :status="fileMenuOpen"
 *   @select="handleFileAction"
 * />
 *
 * @example
 * // With search functionality
 * <InDropdownMenu
 *   id="searchable-menu"
 *   :options="users"
 *   :status="isOpen"
 *   :search-status="true"
 *   @select="selectUser"
 *   @search="filterUsers"
 * />
 *
 * @example
 * // With loading state
 * <InDropdownMenu
 *   id="async-menu"
 *   :options="menuItems"
 *   :status="isOpen"
 *   :loading-state="isLoading"
 *   @select="handleSelect"
 * />
 *
 * @example
 * // TypeScript usage
 * import type { InDropdownMenuEventHandlers, MenuOption } from './InDropdownMenu';
 *
 * const options: MenuOption[] = [
 *   { text: 'Option 1', value: 'opt1', icon: 'check' },
 *   { text: 'Option 2', value: 'opt2', disabled: true }
 * ];
 *
 * const handlers: InDropdownMenuEventHandlers = {
 *   onSelect: (value) => console.log('Selected:', value),
 *   onSearch: (query) => console.log('Searching:', query)
 * };
 */
declare const InDropdownMenu: DefineComponent<InDropdownMenuProps>;

export default InDropdownMenu;

commonMistakes.mistake: Not setting responseKey for API fetch
commonMistakes.solution: Set response-key to match your API response structure

commonMistakes.mistake: Using disable instead of disabled in options

valueFormat.notes: Defines the multi-select items. Each option must have 'label' (display text) and 'value' (selected value). Optional: 'disabled' to prevent selection. For type='checkbox', checkboxes appear next to each option. For type='tags', options show as removable tags when selected.
valueFormat.typescript: Array<{ label: string; value: string | number; disabled?: boolean; }>
valueFormat.example: :options="[{ label: 'Option 1', value: '1' }, { label: 'Option 2', value: '2', disabled: true }]"

commonMistakes.mistake: Using 'text' instead of 'label' for option display
commonMistakes.impact: Options won't display - component expects 'label' property
commonMistakes.fix: Use 'label' property: { label: 'Text', value: 'val' }

valueFormat.notes: Array of currently selected values that match the 'value' properties of selected options. Use v-model for two-way binding. Empty array means no selection. Component automatically adds/removes values when user selects/deselects options.

customOptionsKey.description: Custom property name for option label

valueFormat.notes: Maps custom property names from your data to dropdown's expected format. Use when your API returns objects with different property names than 'label' and 'value'. Example: if API returns [{name: 'John', id: 1}], use ['name', 'id'] to map namelabel and idvalue. Same as InDropDown.

commonMistakes.mistake: Not setting when options have different label key
commonMistakes.impact: Options don't display correctly - shows undefined or [Object object]
commonMistakes.fix: Map your property names: :custom-options-key="['yourLabelKey', 'yourValueKey']"

fetchUrl.description: API endpoint for fetching options dynamically

valueFormat.notes: API endpoint URL to fetch dropdown options dynamically. When set, component will fetch options from this endpoint on mount or when search query changes. Use with 'responseKey' to extract data from nested responses and 'queryString' for search parameter name.

responseKey.description: JSON path to options array in API response

valueFormat.notes: Dot-notation path to extract options array from API response. CRITICAL for API fetching. If API returns {data: {items: [...]}}, use 'data.items'. If response is flat array at root, leave empty or use 'data' if responseHasData=true.

Name of the query parameter for search functionality when using API fetch. The search input value will be sent as this parameter. Example: if queryString='search', API will be called with ?search=userInput. Requires searchStatus=true and fetchUrl to be set.

maxSelectableItem.description: Maximum number of items that can be selected

valueFormat.notes: Limits the number of options that can be selected. When limit is reached, remaining options become disabled and warningMessage is displayed. Use 0 (default) for unlimited selection. Useful for enforcing business rules like 'select up to 5 categories'.

addNewTagStatus.description: Allow creating new options by typing

valueFormat.notes: Enables adding new options on-the-fly when user types value not in the options list. Shows 'Create new' button in dropdown. When clicked, emits 'addNewOption' event with the typed value. Subject to character limits (minimumNewTagCharacterLimit, maxNewTagCharacterLimit).

minimumNewTagCharacterLimit.description: Minimum characters required for new tag

valueFormat.notes: Minimum length required for creating new tags. Default is 2. 'Create new' option only appears when typed text length >= this value. Prevents accidentally creating single-character or empty tags.

maxNewTagCharacterLimit.description: Maximum characters allowed for new tag

valueFormat.notes: Maximum length allowed for creating new tags. Empty string ('') means no limit. When limit is reached, user cannot type more characters. Use to enforce tag naming standards or database constraints.

hasTemporaryOptions.description: Allow temporary options that aren't persisted

valueFormat.notes: When true, newly created options are marked as temporary and may not be persisted to backend. Useful for client-side filtering or preview functionality where new options shouldn't be saved to database immediately.

Controls visual representation of selections. 'checkbox' (default) shows checkboxes next to options, useful for traditional multi-select. 'tags' displays selected items as removable tag chips above dropdown, better for space-constrained UIs.
Visual color theme. 'grey' (default) for standard gray styling, 'light' for lighter background, 'dark' for dark mode. Affects dropdown background, borders, and text colors.

addNewOption.description: Emitted when new option is created

bestPractices.description: Enable search when options > 10 for better UX
Prevent over-selection with clear limits
Use warningMessage and invalidMessage for user feedback
